bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK CITY (ANPD
Southern churches and church
units are removing color bars
from religious worship.


White Methodist jurisdictions
have begun to explore possibili-
ties of merging with Negro con-
ferences, presently grouped to-
gether in the nationwide Central
Jurisdiction.


During its General Assembly
in April, the Southern Presby-
terrain Church ordered integra-
tion of colored and white presby-
teries. Many Southern Presby-
terrain synods have approved the
church's constitutional amend
ment which provided that mo
one shall be excluded from par
ticipation in public worship on
grounds of race, color or class"


1913 congregations of the Luz
theran Church in America have
been urged by the North Carolina
synod to welcome all persons to
worship, regardless of race.


The formerly lily-white En-
Gree Presbytery in South Caro-
lima has voted to admit Negroes.
A Negro clergyman, the Rev.
E. E. Newberry of Charlotte,
North Carolina, was elected mo-
derator of the predominantly
white Mecklenbery Presbytery.


Another Negro Minister, DR..

Negroes and
Whites Integrute
In Church

Harry Richardson of Atlanta,
has been named President of
the Georgia Council of Churches.


Negro ministers have been adj
mitted to membership in the
Minister'S Association of Column
bia, South Carolina, for the first
time.


Spearheading the integration
focus of Baptists, the Rev. c. E.
Aubrey of Dallas, an outstanding
evangelist, recently preached
that "racism is immoral" He
attacked Baptist "footdragging'
on civil rights, contending 1t i'm
pedes the church's missionary
work.


Despite the fact that the South
ern Baptist Convention voted
down strong rights resolution
proposed at its annual convention
in May, 98l of 1907 Texas Bap-
fist churches have quietly opened
their doors to Negroes.


Even Atlanta's First Baptist
Church, from whose steps Neg
roes were hurled bodily last year,
has voted to allow colored wor-
shippers to sit in the sanctuary
along with whites.


In Mississippi, Roman Catho-
lie Bishop has joined with Protes-
tants to form Committee of
Concern under Jackson Baptist
minister, the Rev. William P.
Davis. The purpose of the COM
mittee is to raise funds to rebuild
Negro churches in the state which
have been destroyed or damaged
by racists bomb-throwers.

Those beliefs didn't stick with
us, but preferences in meat cuts
and varieties do, says the Co.
operative Extension Service. By
and large, Americans prefer the
same things their grandparents
did. For example, New Orleans
families eat five times as much
veal as Wisconsinites and al
most all the national output
of sWeetbreads is eaten in New
York City and Los Angeles.

Negroes and
Whites Integrute
In Church
full articles.article:
NEW YORK CITY (ANPD
Southern churches and church
units are removing color bars
from religious worship.


White Methodist jurisdictions
have begun to explore possibili-
ties of merging with Negro con-
ferences, presently grouped to-
gether in the nationwide Central
Jurisdiction.


During its General Assembly
in April, the Southern Presby-
terrain Church ordered integra-
tion of colored and white presby-
teries. Many Southern Presby-
terrain synods have approved the
church's constitutional amend
ment which provided that mo
one shall be excluded from par
ticipation in public worship on
grounds of race, color or class"


1913 congregations of the Luz
theran Church in America have
been urged by the North Carolina
synod to welcome all persons to
worship, regardless of race.


The formerly lily-white En-
Gree Presbytery in South Caro-
lima has voted to admit Negroes.
A Negro clergyman, the Rev.
E. E. Newberry of Charlotte,
North Carolina, was elected mo-
derator of the predominantly
white Mecklenbery Presbytery.


Another Negro Minister, DR..

Harry Richardson of Atlanta,
has been named President of
the Georgia Council of Churches.


Negro ministers have been adj
mitted to membership in the
Minister'S Association of Column
bia, South Carolina, for the first
time.


Spearheading the integration
focus of Baptists, the Rev. c. E.
Aubrey of Dallas, an outstanding
evangelist, recently preached
that "racism is immoral" He
attacked Baptist "footdragging'
on civil rights, contending 1t i'm
pedes the church's missionary
work.


Despite the fact that the South
ern Baptist Convention voted
down strong rights resolution
proposed at its annual convention
in May, 98l of 1907 Texas Bap-
fist churches have quietly opened
their doors to Negroes.


Even Atlanta's First Baptist
Church, from whose steps Neg
roes were hurled bodily last year,
has voted to allow colored wor-
shippers to sit in the sanctuary
along with whites.


In Mississippi, Roman Catho-
lie Bishop has joined with Protes-
tants to form Committee of
Concern under Jackson Baptist
minister, the Rev. William P.
Davis. The purpose of the COM
mittee is to raise funds to rebuild
Negro churches in the state which
have been destroyed or damaged
by racists bomb-throwers.

Those beliefs didn't stick with
us, but preferences in meat cuts
and varieties do, says the Co.
operative Extension Service. By
and large, Americans prefer the
same things their grandparents
did. For example, New Orleans
families eat five times as much
veal as Wisconsinites and al
most all the national output
of sWeetbreads is eaten in New
York City and Los Angeles.
